title: R42621
content: Some in the 112th Congress wanted to cut international affairs spending, including foreign aid programs, to reduce the federal budget deficit. However, others believed a strong foreign affairs budget was crucial for national security and foreign policy interests, potentially saving money by avoiding costly military interventions. Congress considered the FY2013 Department of State, Foreign Operations, and Related Agencies appropriations in light of the Budget Control Act of 2011. In FY2013, Congress passed legislation (H.R. 933) to fund federal programs for the remainder of the fiscal year, including the State-Foreign Operations appropriation. This funding supports international affairs programs and activities, typically representing about 1.5% of the total federal budget. The State-Foreign Operations appropriation, signed into law on March 26, 2013 (P.L. 113-6), supports international affairs programs, including foreign economic and security assistance, contributions to international organizations, State Department and USAID operations, public diplomacy, and international broadcasting. Food aid and certain commissions are also part of these programs but funded separately. The State-Foreign Operations appropriation bill, signed into law on March 26, 2013 (P.L. 113-6), supports international affairs programs, including foreign economic and security assistance, contributions to international organizations, State Department and USAID operations, public diplomacy, and international broadcasting. Food aid and various commissions are funded separately through different appropriations bills. A chart illustrating the organizational structure of the State-Foreign Operations appropriations bill is provided in the report. Abbreviations of terms used throughout the report are also included. The report focuses on accounts funded through the State-Foreign Operations appropriations bill and provides appropriations figures for the entire international affairs budget. The report, focusing on State-Foreign Operations appropriations, provides funding details for international affairs programs. President Obama signed the FY2013 Defense and Military Construction/VA Continuing Resolution, funding accounts at FY2012 levels. The Continuing Appropriations Resolution, 2013 was signed on September 28, 2012. Updated funding by account is shown in Appendix C, excluding sequestration reductions. President Obama signed the Continuing Appropriations Resolution, 2013 (P.L. 112-175) on September 28, 2012, funding the government until March 27, 2013. The resolution would provide 0.612% more than FY2012 levels for State and Foreign Operations non-OCO funded activities, while OCO-designated activities would be funded at the FY2012-enacted level. The annualized State-Foreign Operations funding rate under the CR was estimated to be $53.52 billion. The Senate Appropriations Committee approved its FY2013 State-Foreign Operations appropriations bill, providing $52.3 billion, including $2.3 billion in Overseas Contingency Operations funds. This was 5% below the requested amount and 2% below the FY2012 estimated level. The State Department and Related Agencies were allocated $16.3 billion, with $1.6 billion for OCO, while Foreign Operations received $36.0 billion, including $709.8 million in OCO funds. The House Appropriations Committee approved a FY2013 State-Foreign Operations appropriations bill totaling $48.5 billion, with $8.2 billion for Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO). This amount was 12% less than requested and 9% below the FY2012 estimated levels. The bill allocated $15.8 billion for the Department of State and Related Agencies accounts, including $2.9 billion in OCO funding, and $32.9 billion for Foreign Operations accounts, including $5.4 billion in OCO funding. The House Appropriations Committee approved a FY2013 State-Foreign Operations appropriations bill totaling $48.5 billion, with $8.2 billion for Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO). The Senate allocated $53.02 billion for the State-Foreign Operations subcommittee, 3% less than the Administration's request. The Obama Administration sought a 2.6% increase above the estimated FY2012 level for the Department of State-Foreign Operations and Related Agencies in its FY2013 budget request. The Obama Administration submitted its FY2013 budget request to Congress, seeking a 2.6% increase for the Department of State-Foreign Operations. The total request was $54.9 billion, including $8.2 billion for Overseas Contingency Operations. The FY2013 budget request included a 2.6% increase for State-Foreign Operations, totaling $54.9 billion. It proposed new funds for the Middle East and North Africa Incentive Fund and the Pakistan Counterinsurgency Capability Fund. The FY2013 budget request included a 2.6% increase for State-Foreign Operations, totaling $54.9 billion. It proposed new funds for the Middle East and North Africa Incentive Fund and the Pakistan Counterinsurgency Capability Fund. The FY2013 request reflected changes in funding categories, with slight increases in State Department Administration of Foreign Affairs and security assistance funding. The State-Foreign Operations funding requested for FY2013 included funding for State Department operations, International Organizations, International Peacekeeping activities, International Broadcasting, National Endowment for Democracy, and U.S. Institute of Peace. The State Department and Related Agencies accounts would have seen a 4.5% boost in FY2013 to a total of $18.8 billion. The FY2013 State Department budget request included a 4.5% increase to $18.8 billion, with $14.1 billion allocated for Administration of Foreign Affairs. Key efforts supported included the military-to-civilian transition in Iraq, State Department-led initiatives in Afghanistan and Pakistan, internal reorganizations, and personnel issues. The State Department's FY2013 budget request included a 4.5% increase to $18.8 billion, with $14.1 billion allocated for Administration of Foreign Affairs. The Department has taken over all U.S. programs in Iraq after the military-to-civilian transition, handling responsibilities like air transport and medical support. The Administration requested 23% for FY2013 to support these efforts. The State Department requested $2.7 billion for FY2013, 23% less than FY2012, to support its responsibilities in Iraq post-military transition. This lower funding level reflects the Administration's intent to "normalize" the U.S. presence in Iraq, with cost-saving measures including a reduction in State Department presence and security contracts. The State Department requested reduced funding for FY2013 to support its responsibilities in Iraq post-military transition. Cost-saving measures included a reduction in State Department presence, security contracts, and completion of construction funded in FY2012. The House appropriations bill allocated $2.8 billion for State Department operations in frontline states, with increased security but no funding for additional staff. The Senate Appropriations Committee provided $2.1 billion for Department of State operations in Iraq in FY2013, deemed adequate under revised operational assumptions. The FY2013 budget request reflected reforms outlined in the QDDR. The FY2013 budget request for the State Department in Iraq, totaling $2.1 billion, reflected reforms outlined in the QDDR. The QDDR aimed to shift diplomatic resources to priority countries and programs, leading to the establishment of a new Bureau of Energy Resources and elevation of the Office of the Coordinator for Counterterrorism. Funding for the State Department's operations also supported the Bureau of Conflict and Stabilization Operations. The Office of the Coordinator for Reconstruction and Stabilization activities were absorbed into the Bureau of Conflict and Stabilization Operations. Funding for the State Department's Counterterrorism mission increased to $19 million in FY2013. The Bureau of Counterterrorism requested funds for 12 new positions. The Bureau of Energy Resources sought 22 positions. Neither the House nor Senate bill mentioned the Bureau of Counterterrorism but could still provide funding for new hires within the Diplomatic and Consular Programs account. The Bureau of Energy Resources requested 22 additional direct-hire positions in the FY2013 budget to strengthen market incentives and engage on U.S. global energy priorities. The funding request also included plans to establish regional hubs in Istanbul, Singapore, Johannesburg, and Rio de Janeiro. The Administration's funding request for the Bureau of Energy Resources included plans to establish regional hubs in Istanbul, Singapore, Johannesburg, and Rio de Janeiro. The House Appropriations Committee did not approve the additional $5.4 million and 22 new positions for the Bureau. The Senate Appropriations Committee did not mention this Bureau, but funding within the D&CP could support new hires. The Administration's FY2013 request for the Bureau of Conflict and Stabilization Operations (CSO) saw an 86% increase in funding, with a restructuring to make the Bureau more agile and expeditionary. Staffing levels would decrease by 64 positions. The FY2013 funding for the Bureau of Conflict and Stabilization Operations (CSO) increased by 86% to $56.5 million. Staffing levels were reduced by 64 positions to create a more agile and expeditionary Bureau with a focus on flexible response capacity. The Civilian Response Corps (CRC) model was also modified to fund experts only when deployed, resulting in a reduction of 76 CRC members. The House Appropriations Committee's proposal allowed the Secretary of State to transfer up to $35 million for Conflict and Stabilization Operations. The House Appropriations Committee's FY2013 proposal for Conflict and Stabilization Operations included authority for the Secretary of State to transfer up to $35 million from Diplomatic & Consular Program funding. The Senate Appropriations Committee did not provide funding for CSO but authorized the transfer of $56.5 million from D&CP funding, along with an additional $10 million from the Complex Crisis Fund. The Administration's FY2013 request included $2.5 billion for additional human resources, with $24.9 million allocated to increase State's staffing by 121 new positions. The Administration's FY2013 request for additional human resources D&CP was $2.5 billion, with $24.9 million allocated to increase State's staffing by 121 new positions. Secretary Clinton aimed to increase FSOs by 25% from 2008 to 2014, but with proposed funding, State would reach 18% growth by hiring 82 FSOs and 39 civil servants. The department postponed the goal of 25% growth in the Foreign Service beyond 2014 due to budget constraints. The Administration's FY2013 request for additional human resources D&CP was $2.5 billion, with $24.9 million allocated to increase State's staffing by 121 new positions. Secretary Clinton aimed to increase FSOs by 25% from 2008 to 2014, but with proposed funding, State would reach 18% growth by hiring 82 FSOs and 39 civil servants. The department postponed its goal of 25% growth in the Foreign Service to future years beyond 2014 due to budget constraints. Additionally, $81.4 million was requested for the final phase of implementing Overseas Comparability Pay for FSOs to address previous pay disparities and recruitment challenges. The FY2013 request aimed to address pay disparities for Foreign Service employees, with Congress approving prior adjustments to reduce the pay differential. The House Appropriations Committee did not allocate funds for hiring above attrition and rejected the extension of authority for overseas comparability pay. This issue could impact diplomatic readiness by increasing attrition and recruitment challenges. The House Appropriations Committee rejected funding for hiring above attrition in FY2013 and the extension of authority for overseas comparability pay. The Senate Appropriations Committee also did not include overseas comparability pay authority or funding in its FY2013 proposal. The United States' opposition to Palestinian statehood outside of a negotiated agreement with Israel is being debated in the State-Foreign Operations appropriations process. The U.S. opposes Palestinian statehood outside of negotiations with Israel, withholding funding to U.N. agencies that accept Palestinians as full members. The Administration sought $80 million for UNESCO contributions in 2012, but the House committee report stated they would withhold these funds. In 2012, the House committee report stated that U.S. contributions to UNESCO would be withheld. Both House and Senate legislation included restrictions on funding for the Palestinian Authority if they gain full membership in the United Nations. The proposals also included less funding than requested for International Organizations and Programs. The Foreign Operations budget, managed by USAID and the State Department, includes less funding than requested for International Organizations and Programs. This budget comprises the majority of U.S. foreign assistance programs, with exceptions like food assistance. The Foreign Operations budget, managed by USAID and the State Department, includes funding for various foreign assistance agencies and contributions to multilateral financial institutions. The FY2013 budget request totaled $36.07 billion, a slight increase from the previous year. The FY2013 Foreign Operations budget request totaled $36.07 billion, with a focus on ongoing foreign assistance initiatives and funding for war-related states. Congressional priorities and policy issues like funding restrictions for family planning programs were also highlighted. House and Senate committee actions showed differing priorities in Congress regarding foreign aid funding, including funding levels and policy issues like restrictions on international family planning programs. Recent popular uprisings in the Middle East and North Africa have raised questions about using foreign assistance for democracy promotion, especially in light of the fall of the Mubarak regime in Egypt and the U.S. involvement in ousting Muammar Gaddafi in Libya. The use of foreign assistance for democracy promotion has come under scrutiny, especially after the fall of the Mubarak regime in Egypt and the U.S. involvement in ousting Muammar Gaddafi in Libya. The 112th Congress expressed interest in supporting uprisings against undemocratic regimes but had concerns about accountability and unintended consequences. To address the evolving situation in the Middle East, the Administration proposed a $770 million Middle East and North Africa Incentive Fund in its FY2013 budget request. The Administration proposed a $770 million Middle East and North Africa Incentive Fund in its FY2013 budget request. This fund would support existing programs like the Middle East Partnership Initiative and regional activities. The remaining $700 million would be unallocated funds to incentivize countries to move towards democracy, with State Department flexibility and transparency. The Administration proposed a $770 million Middle East and North Africa Incentive Fund in its FY2013 budget request to support existing programs and incentivize countries towards democracy. Some Members of Congress expressed concerns about the proposed MENA IF, citing potential lack of oversight. The House committee bill allocated $175 million within the Economic Support Fund and $25 million in the Foreign Military Finance account for "Middle East Response," with $50 million designated for Jordan. The Administration proposed a $770 million Middle East and North Africa Incentive Fund in its FY2013 budget request to support existing programs and incentivize countries towards democracy. The House committee bill allocated $175 million within the Economic Support Fund and $25 million in the Foreign Military Finance account for "Middle East Response," with $50 million designated for Jordan. The Senate committee report included $1 billion for MENA IF—about 30% more than the $770 million requested. Afghanistan, Iraq, and Pakistan have been top U.S. aid recipients due to their strategic significance in the Global War on Terror. For FY2013, the Administration requested $6.8 billion for aid to Afghanistan, Iraq, and Pakistan, with $2.1 billion designated for Iraq, including $1.8 billion as OCO funds. The State Department's largest program in Iraq, the Police Development Program, received $1 billion. In 2012, there were concerns about the program being reduced or abandoned. The Police Development Program (PDP) in Iraq, a vital part of U.S.-Iraqi relationship, faced scrutiny in 2012 amid reports of reduction. Despite U.S. Embassy's support, doubts linger due to security challenges and Iraqi indifference. House legislation expressed support for PDP but required Administration to report on revised personnel, scope, and costs. The House report expressed support for the Police Development Program (PDP) in Iraq but required the Administration to report on revised personnel, scope, and costs. The Senate Appropriations Committee did not include funding for the PDP due to Iraqi disinterest and inadequate planning. The Administration requested $2.5 billion in foreign operations funds for Afghanistan in FY2013, with almost half designated as OCO. This reflected a surge in infrastructure programs and investments in economic growth. The Administration requested $2.5 billion in foreign operations funds for Afghanistan in FY2013, with almost half designated as OCO. The increase reflected a surge in infrastructure programs and investments in economic growth, as well as the ramping up of justice sector programs in anticipation of the transition from the Department of Defense to civilian management. The House legislation did not specify total funding for Afghanistan and included a provision to withhold assistance until adequate security is in place for civilian aid workers. The Senate bill included $1.8 billion for Afghanistan, stating that less funding would be needed as the Afghan government takes control of more programs. The Administration requested $2.2 billion in foreign operations funds for Pakistan in FY2013, with $800 million designated for the Pakistan Counterinsurgency Capability Fund. The request included civilian assistance for energy, economic growth, stabilization, education, and health. The House legislation did not specify an aid level for Pakistan, while the Senate bill included $842.3 million for Pakistan, with $50 million for the PCCF. The House legislation did not specify an aid level for Pakistan, and prohibited assistance if Pakistan is uncooperative in anti-terrorism efforts. The Senate bill included $842.3 million for Pakistan, with new conditions on aid including withholding $33 million until Dr. Shakil Afridi is released from prison. The budget request included $7.9 billion for the Global Health Initiative. The budget request included a $300 million cut in global health funding, with reductions in all areas except for family planning and the Global Fund. Bilateral HIV/AIDS activities faced the most significant proposed reductions. The FY2013 budget proposed a 57% increase in funding ($1.7 billion) for the Global Fund to Fight HIV, Tuberculosis, and Malaria, with reductions in bilateral HIV/AIDS activities. The House legislation provided $8 billion for global health, slightly more than the request, including $1.3 billion for the Global Fund. The Senate proposed $8.5 billion for global health, 8% more than requested, including $1.7 billion for the Global Fund. Feed the Future initiative remained a priority with a $1.1 billion request for Foreign Operations funds. The FY2013 budget proposed a 57% increase in funding for the Global Fund to Fight HIV, Tuberculosis, and Malaria, with reductions in bilateral HIV/AIDS activities. Feed the Future initiative remained a priority with a $1.1 billion request for Foreign Operations funds. The FY2013 request included $134 million for the Global Agriculture and Food Security Program. The House proposal for FY2013 supported the goals of Feed the Future but did not specify a funding level, except for $99.8 million allocated for GAFSP. The Senate recommended $1.2 billion for related programs. The FY2013 budget proposed increased funding for global health initiatives, including the Global Fund to Fight HIV, Tuberculosis, and Malaria. The House and Senate proposals supported the goals of the Feed the Future initiative, with specific funding allocated for the Global Agriculture and Food Security Program (GAFSP). The Global Climate Change Initiative (GCCI) received a requested budget of $770 million for activities related to climate change adaptation and clean energy technologies. The Global Climate Change Initiative (GCCI) receives funding from various sources, including World Bank Trust Funds. The House and Senate had differing views on GCCI funding in their FY2013 proposals, with the House recommending zero funding for certain funds and the Senate not specifying a minimum funding level. The House legislation recommended zero funding for the Clean Technology Fund and Strategic Climate Fund, while providing half of the requested funds for the Global Environment Facility. The Senate committee suggested $111 million for Sustainable Landscapes under the GCCI and allocated significant funding for multilateral climate change funds, exceeding the Administration's requests. The Administration requested $643 million for family planning and reproductive health activities in FY2013, a topic of contentious debate in Congress for over three decades. The Administration requested $643 million for family planning and reproductive health activities in FY2013, sparking debate in Congress for over three decades. Recent focus includes the "Mexico City policy" and U.S. funding of the UNFPA. The policy, initiated by President Reagan in 1984, has been rescinded and reissued by past and current Administrations. The Mexico City Policy, initiated by President Reagan in 1984, has been rescinded and reissued by past and current Administrations. President Obama rescinded it in January 2009. The FY2013 House legislation proposed codifying the policy, while the Senate bill did not. Previous Administrations have suspended grants to UNFPA due to evidence of coercive family planning practices in China. The George W. Bush Administration suspended U.S. contributions to UNFPA from FY2002 to FY2008. President Obama resumed U.S. contributions to UNFPA. The George W. Bush Administration suspended U.S. contributions to UNFPA from FY2002 to FY2008 following a State Department investigation of family planning programs in China. President Obama resumed U.S. contributions to the organization in 2009. The proposed FY2013 House legislation included $461 million for family planning and reproductive health activities and prohibited funding for UNFPA, while the Senate legislation included $700 million for family planning and reproductive health, including $44.5 million for UNFPA. Both the House and Senate bills included the Kemp-Kasten amendment. The Administration proposed that the AEECA account be dissolved in FY2013. The Administration proposed to dissolve the AEECA account in FY2013, merging its funds with ESF, GHP, and INCLE accounts. This change reflects the end of special focus on former Soviet and Eastern bloc states transitioning to democracy and free market economies. The House legislation adopted this approach, stating it does not signal diminished support for the region. The Senate proposal also included provisions for using funds from ESF and other accounts to provide assistance to countries. The Senate proposal does not provide a minimum funding level for AEECA-eligible countries, but funds from ESF and other accounts can be used to assist them. U.S. national security, trade promotion, and humanitarian interests drive international affairs activities, which have evolved from an anti-communist focus during the Cold War to include promoting economic development, trade, education, health care, human rights, and environmental protection. After the Cold War, U.S. foreign policy shifted towards objectives like nuclear non-proliferation, drug control, peace efforts in the Middle East, regional stability, religious freedom, and counter-trafficking. Following the 9/11 attacks, national security became a primary focus, with an emphasis on counterterrorism efforts. President Bush's 2002 National Security Strategy included global development as a key component of U.S. national security. In 2002, President Bush established global development as a key component of U.S. national security, alongside defense and diplomacy. Foreign assistance budget priorities shifted towards supporting countries involved in the war on terrorism. Reconstruction programs in Afghanistan and Iraq became prominent in foreign aid budgets, reflecting the use of foreign aid as a tool for national security. Diplomatic security and effectiveness were key focuses for the State Department. The Bush Administration emphasized using foreign aid for national security, with large reconstruction programs in Afghanistan and Iraq. Efforts also focused on diplomatic security and public diplomacy in Muslim communities. Aid was increased for combatting HIV/AIDS globally through PEPFAR, and a new approach to development assistance was explored with the creation of MCC. The Obama Administration continued many of these initiatives, including MCC and global health funding. The Obama Administration continued Bush's foreign aid initiatives, including MCC and global health funding. Funding for these initiatives was requested within Overseas Contingency Operations in regular appropriations bills. The first Quadrennial Diplomacy and Development Review was completed in 2010, naming USAID as the leading agency for development assistance and implementing reforms for the Department of State. In the context of the first Quadrennial Diplomacy and Development Review completed in 2010, the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) was designated as the primary government agency for development assistance. Reforms for the Department of State were also outlined, including the establishment of the Bureau of Energy and elevating the Office of the Coordinator for Stabilization and Reconstruction to the Bureau of Conflict and Stabilization Operations. Additionally, in the FY2012 budget proposals, the Department of State requested a change in funding for Iraq, Afghanistan, and Pakistan, extending Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO) funds to cover temporary costs in these front line states. This request was adopted by Congress in the FY2012 State-Foreign Operations appropriations legislation. The Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO) designation, initially extended to cover temporary costs in Iraq, Afghanistan, and Pakistan, gained significance with the Budget Control Act of 2011. OCO funds do not count towards budget caps but are subject to automatic reductions. This designation helps prevent war-related funding from overshadowing core international affairs activities in the budget allocation. The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) determined that OCO funds are not exempt from BCA automatic reductions starting January 2, 2013. Emergency supplemental funds for foreign operations in Iraq and Afghanistan were not counted towards budget allocations in FY2002-FY2010. The Obama Administration criticized this practice and increased base funding in FY2010, but supplemental funds were still requested and enacted. The Obama Administration increased base funding in FY2010 for international affairs activities, leading to a sharp increase in funding. Supplemental funds were still requested for emergencies like the earthquake in Haiti, but FY2011 saw all international affairs funding appropriated as part of the base budget. The OCO approach was adopted for FY2012, allowing all funding to be considered simultaneously in the regular appropriations process. For FY2013, $8.24 billion was designated as OCO, about 15% of the international affairs request. In FY2013, the Administration requested $8.24 billion, or 15% of the international affairs budget, to be designated as Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO) funding. This was a 5% decrease from the previous year and 26% less than what Congress enacted. The House legislation allocated $8.3 billion as OCO, while the Senate bill allocated $2.3 billion, mainly due to no funding for the Iraq Police Development program. State Department-Foreign Operations funding trended upward until 2011, with a spike in FY2004 for Iraq and Afghanistan reconstruction. FY2011 saw a significant reduction in foreign affairs spending to meet deficit reduction goals. FY2012 and FY2013 funding leveled off due to deficit reduction efforts, remaining below FY2009 levels after adjusting for inflation. See Table 2 and Figure 3 for appropriations over the past decade. State-Foreign Operations appropriations have been below FY2009 levels after adjusting for inflation. State Department funding saw a slight increase in recent years, reflecting efforts to increase human resource capacity. Foreign aid spiked in 2004, but diplomacy funding lagged. Overall, State Department and related agencies funding trends upward at a steeper rate than foreign affairs spending. The George W. Bush and Obama Administrations aimed to boost human resource capacity at the Department of State. Foreign aid appropriations have shown fluctuations over the past decade, with Israel and Egypt historically receiving the most aid. Funding for Iraq has decreased in recent years due to completion of reconstruction efforts. Israel has been the top recipient of U.S. foreign aid since 1978, with Afghanistan and Pakistan also receiving significant amounts. Aid to Iraq has decreased due to completed reconstruction efforts. Afghanistan received $2,505 million in aid, with a portion designated as OCO funds. Pakistan ranked third in aid recipients. In FY2013, Israel received $3,100 million in Foreign Military Financing, Afghanistan ranked second with $2,505 million requested, and Pakistan ranked third at $2,228 million. Aid to Africa would have declined by 10%, aid to the Near East would have increased by 12%, and aid to South Central Asia would have increased by 6%. In FY2013, aid to Africa would have declined by 10%, while aid to the Near East would have increased by 12% and aid to South Central Asia would have increased by 6%. The Near East region's assistance continued to be dominated by Israel, Iraq, Egypt, and Jordan. Europe and Eurasia saw a 14% decline in aid due to progress made by many countries in the region. East Asia and Pacific aid remained relatively low and consistent with past years' levels. Aid to East Asia and Pacific remained low and consistent with past years' levels. Congress has shown interest in various aid sectors like education, trade capacity, maternal and child health, and biodiversity. Administrations present budget requests highlighting key interest areas, but comparison data is limited. Comparing FY2012 and FY2013 budget requests provides insight into Administration's priorities. The Administration's FY2013 budget request showed declines in funding for key interest areas compared to FY2012, including Food Security and Global Climate Change. Other sectors with reduced funding requests included Sustainable Landscapes, Neglected Tropical Diseases, Nutrition, Maternal and Child Health, Higher Education, Clean Energy, and Basic Education. Increased funding was emphasized for Gender Funding. The Administration's FY2013 budget request included increased funding for Gender Funding and Science, Technology, and Innovation, while reducing funding for key interest areas such as Food Security and Global Climate Change. Other sectors with decreased funding requests included Sustainable Landscapes, Neglected Tropical Diseases, Nutrition, Maternal and Child Health, Higher Education, Clean Energy, and Basic Education.
